title: Wednesday, 18th November, 2015

11:04 am
PM

 There is a new article (http://ftalphavill...-wirecard-buying/), on the Alphaville blog
page, about Wirecard strategy, acquisition and accounting.
 This time, the usual author (Dan MacCrum – who clearly has an agenda) questions the latest business acquired called Great
Indian retail Group (click to read our note).
 What this new article puts in doubt is 1/ the reality of the business (saying this business was barely involved in payment 2 years
ago) and 2/ the accounting of revenues, gross margins, receivables and payables.
 As a reminder, Wirecard said that this group was operating in India Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia, that the price was
€230m (+€100m depending on the performance), and that revenues were growing by 50%, with doubling Ebitda.
 Our view
1/ it is not the first time this contributor to the Alphavile blog writes on Wirecard,
2/ Again, the article does not prove anything (it even reminds that the group talked about intensive internal and external legal,
financial and tax due diligence), but casts doubt on the acquisition policy of Wirecard even if the article seems to suggest that
Wirecard has answered to some of its questions
3/ This new article should weigh on the share again, but the effect have been short lived recently
4/ Wirecard will publish its Q3 earnings on November 18 and will probably answer to analyst questions on that matter…

PM

There's no individual analyst named on that note

PM

And that's all it says, bar a page of disclosures

Dan MacCrum – who clearly has an agenda

Defamatory, yeah?

There are specifics, such as Goldman turning slightly less negative on 'Fags.

11:13 am
Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 484.40, up 12 (+2.54%), High: 485.60, Low: 465.90, Volume: 1.04m
BE

We upgrade Antofagasta to Neutral from Sell. Since being added to the
Sell List on February 23, 2015 the stock is -35.1% vs the FTSE World
Europe -8.3% (in GBP). We attribute the underperformance to operational
issues at Anto’s mines in Chile, a slump in copper prices, and a rich price
paid for the 50% stake in the Zaldivar mine. At the current depressed price
and with spot copper prices now within c.5% of our trough forecasts, we
believe the risk/reward for the stock is now balanced. Our 12-month price
target remains 440p.

BE

We remain bearish on copper prices over the near term and see risks to
our forecast skewed to the downside as we believe slowing demand
growth from China implies the announced supply cuts to date and
potential supply cuts to come are on the wrong side of the cost curve.
While the operational issues at Anto’s mines are not completely resolved
(see Operational issues continue in 3Q amid falling copper prices,
published on October 29, 2015), we believe that, in an environment of
sustained low copper prices, investor preference is likely to be skewed to
balance sheet strength over near-term volume growth. On our numbers,
despite what we view as a rich price paid by Anto for the 50% stake in the
Zaldivar mine, it still has one of the most robust balance sheets within our
coverage, with an average net debt/EBITDA of 0.4x over FY15-17E vs. our
an average of 1.6x for our European industrial miners coverage.

11:14 am
BE

We value Antofagasta using a pro-forma model (including the 50% stake in
Zaldivar) at a 5.75x EV/EBITDA applied to our 2016 estimates. Our 12-
month price target is unchanged at 440p.

The key risks to our thesis include: higher/lower-than-forecast copper
prices; weaker/stronger CLP vs. USD; improving/worsening operational
performance at its mines; and further delays at Antucoya.

BE

I guess, you need to hold a miner, it may as well be 'Fags. Even though management has called the copper market exactly wrong for about five years straight.

PM

Interesting

11:15 am
PM

GS note there that they remain bearish on copper in the short term

PM

But their metals team are actually quite alarmish, re china

PM

let me get

11:16 am
PM

Rising SHFE open interest may flag China demand deterioration

PM

Metals prices have declined by 12%-17% since late October. Over this
period, China’s economic data for October has disappointed, the US dollar
has strengthened on a trade weighted basis, and the broader commodity
complex has moved lower, including most notably, energy prices.

PM

What has also occurred since late October has been an eye catching rise in
Shanghai Futures Exchange open interest across the metals complex – for
copper, it has been the largest increase in Shanghai open interest in 12
months – since the 1Q15 collapse in Chinese metals demand. In our view,
this development raises a red flag regarding ongoing and near term
activity in China’s ‘old economy’ and metals demand growth, as measured
by our GS China Metals Consumption Index (see chart below). Indeed,
over the past five years, periods of rising SHFE open interest and falling
metals prices have been associated with concurrent or imminent
weakening in China’s commodity intensive ‘old economy’.

11:16 am
PM

Meanwhile, though LME and Comex net speculative positioning has also
declined over the period, it remains well above its August 2015 lows.

PM

Overall, the metals market appears to be increasingly pricing concurrent
and/or future weakness in China’s old economy, and related metals
demand. To the extent that the metals market positioning predicts ongoing
and potential future China growth weakness – since mid-2011 SHFE open
interest has given a correct bearish signal on four out of five occasions –
the latest metal market developments have bearish implications for China’s
upcoming activity data releases and asset classes dependent on this data.

PM

Fresh angle, eh?

11:17 am
BE

Ta .... As for the sector .....

Drax Group PLC (DRX:LSE): Last: 216.80, down 9.7 (-4.28%), High: 226.70, Low: 216.70, Volume: 396.95k
BE

Poor old Drax.

11:19 am
BE

The hits just keep coming.

BE

Today's is the Government confirming plans to phase out unbated coal

BE

As in, coal without carbon capture flumes.

11:20 am
BE

Flumes? However carbon's captured. Dunno. Someone on the right will probably tell me.

BE

Statement here: https://www.gov.uk...r-stations-by-2025

BE

The upshot is consultation due in spring 2016

11:21 am
BE

Initial proposal is to close all plants by 2025, with restricted use from 2023

BE

@FJP wonders why Drax won't be ready ......

BE

I guess the answer to that is that regulation changes every couple of months.

11:23 am
BE

Here's Deutsche Bank, happy for another opportunity to market its recent sell advice.

BE

This could shorten the life for Drax’s remaining coal units unless it can convert more units to biomass or retrofit carbon capture and storage technology.

BE

Low carbon options for Drax
Drax has already converted three of its six coal units to biomass and has said it would be open to converting more units if appropriate government support is made available. It has also worked on development plans to trial carbon capture and storage technology, although recently withdrew from the White Rose Project. Today’s announcement will refocus attention on low carbon options to extend the life of the non-biomass units, although uncertainties remain over whether additional government funding will be made available.

11:23 am
BE

Earlier closure of units could knock 10-20p/share off value
We currently model the closure of Drax’s three coal units in 2027. Closure of these units in 2025 could cut our valuation by 10-20p/share depending on the extent to which associated fixed costs could be reduced. Of course both these scenarios could prove too pessimistic if Drax converts more units away from unabated coal. We model a longer life for Drax’s three biomass units. RO subsidies for its biomass units are due to expire in 2027, although we assume that the units run for a further 10 years with a £5/MWh margin, supporting our c.£500m terminal value estimate for the station in 2027.

BE

A challenging outlook
As we highlighted in our report Drax Group – Power price crunch worsens; downgrade to Sell from 10 November, UK power market pressures are becoming increasingly severe. UK power and gas prices have weakened meaningfully and are likely to put pressure on Drax’s earnings and cashflow. While there are upside option for the shares, the outlook looks challenging if power prices do not improve above levels implied by current market forwards.

BE

And Jefferies.

11:24 am
BE

Wasn't this going to happen anyway? Whilst this is the first time the government has
put a specific date on the closure of the coal fleet, the assumption underlying UK energy
policy for many years has been that coal would be phased out by the mid part of the next
decade. In all of the power sector scenarios produced by DECC et al, coal has all but be been eliminated by 2025. This announcement is not, therefore, a change of policy but is rather a confirmation of existing goals.

BE

Security of Supply: whilst the coal plants in the UK are aging they do offer robust and
flexible generation. A good rule of thumb is that to maintain the same level of security of
supply for each 1GW of coal capacity lost, a minimum of 2GW of renewables (wind) PLUS
0.5GW of gas-fired capacity is required. The UK currently has 19GW of coal capacity, of
which 6GW has been slated for closure before next winter. Crucially coal currently accounts
for around one-third of UK dis-patchable generation and produced 101TWh in 2014 (30%
of total production).

BE

Company impact. We see little impact for SSE, who currently operate 2.5GW of coal
capacity, as they have already written down its coal stations assuming closure in 2023. The
impact may be larger for Drax as three of its c.645MW units run on coal. We had previously
assumed that the coal units would close in 2027 (or converted to biomass if the necessary
support was available). This announcement effectively brings forward the probable closure
date of Drax's three coal units by two years.
Comment: This particular announcement does not alter UK energy policy in any
meaningful way. The coal plants have been slated for closure by the mid-2020's in any
case. But by putting a specific date by which coal will be phased out, the government will
naturally focus attention on security of supply, and the key issue of revitalising the gas-fired
generation new build program.

11:31 am

BE

PM

Why, cos of a possible bid?

11:31 am
BE

Nope. Just too cheap. Shale recovers eventually.

BE

We reiterate our Buy rating on Hunting and add the stock to the Conviction
List as we believe the valuation offers a very good buying opportunity at 2017
EV/EBITDA of 6.1x on our estimates and 6.5x on the Bloomberg consensus vs.
a 5-year average of 10.9x. We expect revenue growth and margin expansion
to start from 2H16 as US onshore drilling activity picks up. We do not see
risks to the balance sheet given that we expect Hunting to remain FCF positive
through 2015/16. Last, within our Europe sector coverage, Hunting is among
the few companies offering exposure to US shale, where we expect a sharp
recovery in 2017 onshore rig levels.

BE

We expect 2015 to see the earnings trough, with no profitability at the group
level in 2H15. In our view, the key catalyst for the stock will be a gradual
pick-up in rig count in the US in 2016 following a trough at the beginning of
next year. On our estimates, the key recovery year is 2017, when we expect
US rig count to rebound by c.50% yoy; we think this pick-up in volumes is
not being priced both in terms of revenue and margins. We see no major
balance sheet risks for Hunting; leverage levels are comfortable (net
debt/EBITDA of 1.3x in 2016E and 0.5x in 2017E). In addition, the company
recently renewed credit lines with banks. The absence of balance sheet
pressures, capex flexibility, growth opportunities, and an attractive
valuation makes the stock an attractive investment in our view.

11:32 am
BE

The stock trades on 2016/17E EV/EBITDA of 12.4x/6.1x. Our 12-month price
target decreases to 546.40p (from 560.10p) on the back of our revised
estimates. Our price target is derived from a 10x 2017E EV/EBITDA
(unchanged) and implies 77% upside.

BE

So. Rig count troughs in Q1.

PM

77% -- quite a call

11:01 am
PM

BE

BE

International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 574.36, down 17.14 (-2.90%), High: 588.50, Low: 574.36, Volume: 2.42m
easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,685, down 25 (-1.46%), High: 1,708, Low: 1,673, Volume: 921.15k
11:34 am
PM

Goodbody rather negative on Easyjet

PM

Tho saying "hold"

PM

difficult balancing act between brand and costs

11:35 am
PM

FY15 pretax profits of £686m fell slightly short of the mid-point of the £675-700m guidance
given in early September and, therefore, expectations. Following on from the results’
release, the briefing was also seen as disappointing as not enough detail on the forecast
FY16 unit cost inflation of 2% was given. In fact. FY15 had a number of one-off costs
amounting to £23m, so easyJet’s forecasts are either leaving something in the tank or
underlying cost inflation is closer to 3.2% this year.
At the same time as easyJet is forecasting rising unit costs, it has guided for a ‘slight decline’
in yield over H116. However, we think that the all-important FY16 summer-season (its H216
period) will be much tougher as other airlines, with better fuel hedges, pass on a significant
proportion of savings to customers. In addition, foreign currency movements are expected to
have a 1% negative impact this year and 2% next.

PM

Further yield pressure is expected as Ryanair’s push into primary airports will become an
increasing disruptor to the status quo over the next three years. This will make easyJet’s
focus on cost even more critical as it balances brand investment against falling yields.
In terms of our valuation, we base this on applying the appropriate multiple on capital
employed for any given ROCE; with forecast ROCE static and a lower denominator, our fair
value falls 70p to £18.30. Hold.

undefined

Stobart Group Ltd (STOB:LSE): Last: 103.90, up 1.9 (+1.86%), High: 105.75, Low: 103.00, Volume: 17.98k

BE

11:43 am
BE

Is it some kind of siege? Are they trying to put each other out of business? Anyway, have some Investec on UK Mail.

BE

H1 results are c.30% ahead of our forecasts. However, the recovery in Parcels margin will take longer than expected with arrivals scheduling now problematic and Mail margins are lower than anticipated due to competitive bidding to win volume. A plan is in place to address scheduling issues and a new COO is due to arrive from Parcelforce early next year. DPS has been rebased by 25% to an interim dividend of 5.5p, implying a 4.5% yield at 364p. We reduce our TP from 485p to 380p, and recommendation from BUY to ADD.

H1 Results: The H1 results were 30% ahead of our forecasts, with underlying operating profit of £5.2m, compared to our estimate of £4.0m. Divisionally, Mail operating profit was 15% below our forecasts, as strong volume growth of 8.1% was offset by lower price and margin to increase share in a market down 5%. Parcels were stronger than we had forecast due to a shallower fall in margin than we expected (albeit with a slower recovery now forecast). DPS has been rebased to 5.5p, from 7.3p.
Changes to Forecasts: Changes to our forecasts largely reflect a slower improvement in Parcels margins. The churn of “ugly” freight is now largely complete, however, UK Mail needs to optimise the scheduling of parcels into the sorting centre throughout the day, to achieve a more even spread. We expect this process to be completed around Autumn 2016. Importantly, parcel pricing is firmer than previously anticipated, with Christmas capacity increasingly scarce. We have reduced our Mail margin assumptions, largely due to very competitive pricing to gain market share. The rollout of automated packet sorting, expected to commence in Q1 FY17e, may be positive to both revenue and margin forecasts. We forecast a dividend of 16.5p for FY16e, cover of 0.9x, rising to 18.2p in FY17e, cover of 1.2x.
Valuation and Recommendation: Given ongoing headwinds, we downgrade our target price from 485p to 380p, based on a FY17 P/E of 17x, taking into account the recovery potential to EPS. Our 380p target price implies a total return of 9.2% and we move our recommendation to ADD from Buy.

BE

Which reminds me .....

11:44 am
BE

The ever-readable Neil Campling at Aviate talked about mail delivery on the back of the DX warning.

BE

I remember it mostly because of the list of companies he put together that are trying to disrupt mail.

BE

Uber has entered the New York parcels delivery market with a business they call UberRush and it is not just Uber.

Here is a list of start-ups going after the logistics, freight-forwarding, delivery markets: Postmates.com is transforming the way local goods move around a city by enabling anyone to get any product delivered in under one hour. Instacart.com delivers groceries in under an hour; Deliv.co bridges the last mile gap between retailers and customers; nimber.com is a crowd sourced delivery system; friendshipper.com allows you to send parcels overseas with a traveller, piggybee.com offers similar and Shyp.com is a price comparison site. Not only is their greater competition, but technology is a deflationary force on price. There are even storage solutions that will eat at the supply-chain logistics margins, for example renting storage from your neighbours, see rooost.com.

11:46 am
BE

Just look at that. Look at all the VC money being burnt.

PM

scorchedfingers

BE

"Friendshipper" .... "Nimber" ..... "Deliv.co" ........

11:46 am
PM

Sound like Rocket subsidiaries

BE

All trying to shake up the hopelessly, perhaps structurally unprofitable market of putting parcels on doorsteps.

BE

Deutsche Post is another company which is potentially impacted. Recent commentary from DPW feels a little like management is scrambling and re-calibrating strategic plans (and should borders become more policed in Europe, compliance costs for Logistics companies may rise). Can they really compete head-to-head if the industry attracts the tech-innovators? Who knows? Time will tell but as with Pearson, Swatch and the German automakers, we don’t intend to hang around to find out.

11:47 am
Royal Mail PLC (RMG:LSE): Last: 454.20, down 0.5 (-0.11%), High: 455.90, Low: 452.00, Volume: 866.38k

PM

BE

11:50 am
BE

In terms of results, I guess there's Soco.

SOCO International PLC (SIA:LSE): Last: 144.50, down 33.5 (-18.82%), High: 163.50, Low: 135.50, Volume: 1.14m
BE

Warns on 2016 production.

11:50 am
BE

"preliminary 2016 Group production guidance at 10-11.5kboe/d"

BE

Market was on for flat production next year. This'll be about 16 per cent lower.

BE

Jefferies is not happy.

11:51 am
BE

The principal reason is that new H5 block production of c.9kb/d gross "is below the c.11-12kb/d originally targeted" and, secondly, the 2016 work programme has yet to be agreed among the partners. 10kboe/d Group production assumes no new drilling at TGT (and US$4m net capex) and 11.5kboe/d assumes 4-5 new wells (and $47m net capex).

BE

Our starting point was growth then flat production. In September, we took our TGT production assumptions down to "roughly flat" out to 2020 even with additional volumes from Full Field Development (FDP). However, ahead of that, our 11.4kboe/d Group production estimate for 2015 (86% of which is from the TGT field offshore Vietnam) grew 16% y/y to 13.3kboe/d in 2016 with new production from the "H5" block offsetting declines in the main part of the field. FDP work (once approved) would then provide production support but at a roughly flat level (in contrast to the significant production growth suggested by Soco's FY14 presentation).

BE

Production decline even with H5 and with new wells? Ironically, updated production guidance for 2015 of 11.8-12.0kboe/d is narrowed to the upper end of the previous range but TGT impacts and an expectation that Soco's second Vietnam field, CNV (~14% of Group production), will produce at a level c.25% below 2015 next year due to reduced reservoir pressure means a 4th straight year of group production decline. Our price target reduces, our cashflow estimates reduce, and, while we already assumed no dividend for 2016, we also reduce our 2017 dividend estimate to 4.8p/sh or ~40% of its previous level.

11:52 am
BE

Valuation/Risks
The stock has held up well above the 150p price target we moved to in September using a US $85/b long-term oil price and risking the incremental FDP production at 50%. This reduces 10% to 135p/sh updating for today's trading statement. Trading at U$18/b 2P reserves, SIA is at a premium for the good things in the stock (net cash, zero debt, dividend paying) but consistent y/y production declines will start to weigh on the name. Our revised price target, implying US$14/boe 2P reserves, is still a fair metric.

BE

Though I don't think Soco has much of a following any more. Bid angle collapsed with WTI, I guess.

Peel Hunt's Nick Batram goes through Desmond's points one-by-one

BE

Mostly saying, "yes, but what's the alternative?"

11:57 am
BE

1) The CMA process will take time and potentially require the disposal of up to
1,000 shops. Not only is the time consumption unhelpful, but a forced disposal
would strengthen the hand of competitors.
PH view. This is a valid point and much depends on the quantum of required
disposals. Unfortunately, in our opinion, the CMA doesn’t have a good track
record when it comes to what we would consider pragmatic decisions in the
leisure sector. Nevertheless, if the required disposals are below 500, this would be
a reasonable outcome.

BE

2) Lost profits of any such disposals may outweigh unspecified synergies.
PH view: Again this is a valid argument, and much will depend on the scale of
disposals. Nevertheless, we do believe Ladbrokes could benefit from Coral’s
trading expertise.

BE

3) LBO sports margins are heading down and greater exposure to retail is
not where the Group should be in the long run.
PH view. It is true that Paddy Power’s retail margins are well below that of other
retail bookmakers, but this has been the case for some time now. In addition, the
roll-out of SSBTs should offset any potential OTC margin erosion. However,
ultimately, Ladbrokes Coral will need to increase its online scale to deliver the
full potential of the enlarged group.

11:57 am
BE

4) Raising the profile of FOBTs is politically dangerous.
PH view. Firstly, highlighting this is doing the very thing Mr Desmond is
warning about. Secondly, much of Ladbrokes’ growth has come from B3
content, not B2 (or FOBTs as they used to be called).

BE

5) The deal is really a Coral acquisition of Ladbrokes.
PH view. Little credit is being given to the quality of the Coral management
team and performance of the core business over the past few years. We do believe
the combined entity will be a better business than Ladbrokes on its own.
However, there is still considerable risk with the transaction and, if a bidder were
to appear, then shareholders would likely be tempted.

BE

6) Lack of technology IP.
PH view. There is no doubt there is a reliance on Playtech and other third-party
software suppliers. However, the well-trodden path in the industry is to establish
a solid base and then build out proprietary technology in certain areas over time.
This is what Paddy Power and William Hill have done.

11:58 am
BE

7) Payment of £75m to Playtech is not justified.
PH view. This is difficult to argue with. The settlement with Playtech does look
generous. Having said that, Playtech is a key supplier and its substantial
engagement in the deal is a positive.

BE

8) Share price reaction to the deal (-16%) is a reflection of market’s
antipathy.
PH view. It is fair to say the market hasn’t really embraced the deal. In part this
is because there is a real concern the CMA will block it. Also, as mentioned
above, we don’t believe the market is giving credit to the quality of the Coral
management team or business

BE

And to conclude ...........

11:58 am
BE

Conclusion: Mr Desmond highlights some valid concerns with the deal. Is it a
deal made in heaven? No. But, if the CMA is not too onerous, then we believe
there is good upside from here. Indeed, our Buy recommendation is based on the
view that upside presented from either Plan A (merger with Corals) or Plan B
(organic recovery) is greater than the downside. At this stage Mr Desmond hasn’t
really come up with much of a Plan C, other than appointing an independent
investment bank to review options – how many strategic reviews does Ladbrokes
need? However, this may just act as a catalyst to encourage others to throw their
hats into the ring, and from this perspective shareholders might just thank Mr
Desmond.

BE

Which is all fair enough.
